comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The evicting force came in the early forenoon to find the house locked and barricaded against them, while the yards and adjoining fields were crowded with sympathetic neighbours and townspeople who had been summoned by the ringing of Church bells and blowing of horns. To a demand for possession, Tim Hurley replied that if they wanted possession they'd have to fight for it. When the bailiffs rushed with a battering ram against the shuttered parlour window, they were met with showers of scalding water from the upstairs windows. The eviction failed! www.failteromhat.com/castleviewevictions.php

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks Niall. Good clear account, but no light cast on the Land League Hut...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Arrangements had been made to build a hut for the evicted tenant if the eviction were successful, and in the evening about two thousand persons assembled in the town with thirty carts, and conveyed the materials of the hut to Hurley's holding, near Hurley's holding, near which they erected it. Bands were in attendance, and the proceedings were marked by great rejoicings. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/75850828

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Excellent! That explains the hut then - well done, Trove! And you too, Niall...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Brilliant poster Carol, this is terrific.  The poor auld peelers suffered in the course of the affray even if they had nothing to gain from it!  Falling into the trap was probably painful and scalding water on your head can exacerbate the dandruff something fierce:-))))

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Don't you run away just yet! Can you have a look and see which chap might be Head Constable Brooks?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From the Trove link: Inspector Carr ranged his men in line of fire and declared he would fire if the resisting force did not cease. The threat 'was received with defiance, but the local clergy who had by this time come on the scene counselled peace; That suggests the man directing the line of constables with rifles and being addressed by the excitable clergyman is Inspector Carr. From this RIC page, I think the Head Constable (highest non-commissioned rank) could be wearing a pillbox hat, so that may be Brooks directing the ram at top left.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Call to Arms, Flickroonies! There's a photo of Scotch Street in Armagh over on NIrelandeye's photostream. He has circa 1880 as a date for it, but wants to be as accurate as possible. Can you help him out?
